**Dwight Kurt Schrute III** [/ˈʃruːt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English") is a [fictional character](/wiki/Fictional_character
"Fictional character") on _[The Office (U.S. TV
series)](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Office \(U.S. TV series\)")_
, portrayed by [Rainn Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson"), and based on
[Gareth Keenan](/wiki/Gareth_Keenan "Gareth Keenan") from the original [UK
series](/wiki/The_Office_\(UK_TV_series\) "The Office \(UK TV series\)"). His
character is one of the highest-ranking salesmen as well as assistant (to the)
regional manager[1] at the paper distribution company [Dunder
Mifflin](/wiki/Dunder_Mifflin "Dunder Mifflin"), although the series expands
on his character as bed-and-breakfast proprietor at Schrute Farms, a beet
plantation, and as the owner of the business park enclosing Dunder Mifflin. He
is notorious for his lack of social skills and common sense, his love for
martial arts and the justice system, and his office rivalry with fellow
salesman [Jim Halpert](/wiki/Jim_Halpert "Jim Halpert"). He is also known for
his love relationship with Angela. He has at times risen to the position of
acting Branch Manager of the Scranton branch, but often serves as a second or
third in command as Assistant (to the) Regional Manager. In the final season,
Dwight is finally offered the position of permanent Regional Manager.

## Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Casting")]

Further information: [Rainn Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/RainnwilsonOct07.jpg/220px-
RainnwilsonOct07.jpg)](/wiki/File:RainnwilsonOct07.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RainnwilsonOct07.jpg "Enlarge")

[Rainn Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson") portrays Dwight Schrute

Dwight Schrute is portrayed by American actor [Rainn
Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson"). In a [Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone") interview, [Seth
Rogen](/wiki/Seth_Rogen "Seth Rogen") said he auditioned for the role. The
character is based on [Gareth Keenan](/wiki/Gareth_Keenan "Gareth Keenan") of
the [original British version of the show](/wiki/The_Office_\(UK_TV_series\)
"The Office \(UK TV series\)"), who was played by actor [Mackenzie
Crook](/wiki/Mackenzie_Crook "Mackenzie Crook").

All original series characters were adapted for the U.S. version. Unlike
[Steve Carell](/wiki/Steve_Carell "Steve Carell"), Wilson watched every
episode of the original British series, and was a fan before he auditioned for
the U.S. version.[2] Wilson had originally auditioned for [Michael
Scott](/wiki/Michael_Scott_\(The_Office\) "Michael Scott \(The Office\)"), a
performance he described as a "terrible [Gervais](/wiki/Ricky_Gervais "Ricky
Gervais") impersonation";[2] however, the casting directors liked his audition
as Dwight much more, and hired him for the role. Wilson based Dwight's
hairstyle on the style he himself had when at the age of sixteen.[2] In an
interview, he said that he went to a [barber](/wiki/Barber "Barber") to get
"the worst haircut possible".[3]

## Character
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Character information")]

When the series begins, Dwight Schrute is a competent salesman, despite
lacking general knowledge, at the [Scranton](/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania
"Scranton, Pennsylvania") branch of the [paper](/wiki/Paper "Paper")
distribution company, [Dunder Mifflin](/wiki/Dunder_Mifflin "Dunder Mifflin").
Dwight formally held the title of "Assistant to the Regional Manager",[4] but
constantly refers to himself as "Assistant Regional Manager", attempting to
elevate himself to second-in-command to branch Manager, Michael Scott.
(Michael privately makes him Assistant Manager in "[The
Fight](/wiki/The_Fight_\(The_Office\) "The Fight \(The Office\)")", tells him
that no record/mention will be kept of the "title change only", then never
acknowledges it again.) Dwight craves authority over his co-workers, and
relishes any minor task that Michael or anyone else will give him.[2] Although
Dwight acts superior to many individuals and is often resourceful in crises,
he is shown to actually be quite gullible, ignorant, and naïve.[2] For this
reason, he is easily tricked and pranked by his desk-mate and fellow salesman,
Jim Halpert.[5]

Dwight often speaks in a halting, intense manner, even in casual
conversations.[2] At the office, his most recurring formal wear is a
[mustard](/wiki/Mustard_\(color\) "Mustard \(color\)")-colored, short-sleeved
collared [shirt](/wiki/Shirt "Shirt"), with a dark [necktie](/wiki/Necktie
"Necktie") and, usually, a brown suit jacket. He often uses [one-
upmanship](/wiki/One-upmanship "One-upmanship") to better himself over his
peers, such as boasting about how he trains specific parts of his body. Dwight
will sometimes engage in jokes and games in attempts to please Michael, but
often fails to do so, because of Michael's perception of himself as the
jokester of the workplace. After Dwight temporarily leaves Dunder Mifflin, it
is shown that he had long been watering the office plant and arranging the
toys on Michael's desk in a manner that made Michael happy, unbeknownst to
Michael.

Dwight is a former [volunteer sheriff deputy](/wiki/Auxiliary_police
"Auxiliary police"),[6] but has to step down after breaking his pledge by
helping his boss pass his drug test in the episode 'Drug Testing'. He is also
a [notary public](/wiki/Notary_public "Notary public"); this creates
difficulties when Angela desires to send him a notarized letter regarding
their break-up. He resides on his family's [beet](/wiki/Beet "Beet")
[farm](/wiki/Farm "Farm"), alongside his [cousin](/wiki/Cousin "Cousin"),
[Mose](/wiki/List_of_characters_from_The_Office_\(US_T.V._series\)#Mose_Schrute
"List of characters from The Office \(US T.V. series\)") (played by
producer/writer [Michael Schur](/wiki/Michael_Schur "Michael Schur")). Dwight
has affinities for [paintball](/wiki/Paintball "Paintball"), _[Battlestar
Galactica](/wiki/Battlestar_Galactica "Battlestar Galactica")_ , [ping
pong](/wiki/Ping_pong "Ping pong"), [survivalism](/wiki/Survivalism
"Survivalism"), [Goju Ryu](/wiki/G%C5%8Dj%C5%AB-ry%C5%AB "Gōjū-ryū") karate[7]
and [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon"). He also has a preference to ride in the
back seat of [cars](/wiki/Cars "Cars") behind the driver, because it is the
safest location in a car.

In "[Whistleblower](/wiki/Whistleblower_\(The_Office\) "Whistleblower \(The
Office\)")", encouraged to invest in [real estate](/wiki/Real_estate "Real
estate") by former [CEO](/wiki/CEO "CEO") and owner of Dunder Mifflin, [Jo
Bennett](/wiki/Jo_Bennett "Jo Bennett"), Dwight decides to purchase the
industrial park building. He has shown entrepreneurial traits, like converting
the building lobby into a coffee shop in
"[Nepotism](/wiki/Nepotism_\(The_Office\) "Nepotism \(The Office\)")",
converting an empty room in the office building into a state-of-the-art
[gym](/wiki/Gym "Gym") in "[Mrs. California](/wiki/Mrs._California "Mrs.
California")", and organizing a barn maze before [Halloween](/wiki/Halloween
"Halloween"), where kids can pay admission to play, in
"[WUPHF.com](/wiki/WUPHF.com "WUPHF.com")".

In an episode commentary on the [season
one](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_1\) "The Office \(U.S. season 1\)")
[DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD"), Wilson refers to Dwight as a "[fascist](/wiki/Fascist
"Fascist") [nerd](/wiki/Nerd "Nerd")". In a feature on the [season
three](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_3\) "The Office \(U.S. season 3\)") DVD,
Wilson describes Dwight as "someone who does not hate the system, but has a
deep and abiding love for it".[8]

All throughout the series Dwight drives a maroon 1987 Pontiac Trans Am, until
the finale where he owns an orange 2012 Dodge Challenger.

### Family and
childhood[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Family and childhood")]

In "[Lecture Circuit](/wiki/Lecture_Circuit "Lecture Circuit")", Dwight claims
to remember his own [birth](/wiki/Birth "Birth"), including his father, Dwight
Schrute II, delivering him from the [womb](/wiki/Womb "Womb"), and his mother
biting off the [umbilical cord](/wiki/Umbilical_cord "Umbilical cord").[9] In
"[Grief Counseling](/wiki/Grief_Counseling_\(The_Office\) "Grief Counseling
\(The Office\)")", Dwight states that he was a twin, but he "resorbed" his
twin while still in his mother's womb (this occurrence is called [twin
embolisation syndrome](/wiki/Absorbed_twin "Absorbed twin")), causing him to
believe that he now has "the strength of a grown man and a little
[baby](/wiki/Baby "Baby")". He also claims to have been born weighing 13 lb 5
oz (6.0 kg), rendering his mother incapable of walking for three months and
two days,[10] and in "[Baby Shower](/wiki/Baby_Shower "Baby Shower")", he
claims to have performed his own [circumcision](/wiki/Circumcision
"Circumcision"). In "[Viewing Party](/wiki/Viewing_Party "Viewing Party")", he
informs [Jim](/wiki/Jim_Halpert "Jim Halpert") and [Pam
Halpert](/wiki/Pam_Beesly "Pam Beesly") that, in the Schrute family, the
youngest child raises the other children.

Little is known about Dwight's parents, except that his father used to take
him [hunting](/wiki/Hunting "Hunting"), cheated in [games](/wiki/Game "Game"),
made him and his siblings biscuits for breakfast every morning, and that he
battled [obesity](/wiki/Obesity "Obesity"), high [blood
pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure "Blood pressure"), and high
[cholesterol](/wiki/Cholesterol "Cholesterol").

Dwight's maternal grandfather, whose surname is Manheim (according to Dwight's
web log on [NBC.com](/wiki/NBC "NBC"))[11] fought in the [Second World
War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"). He killed twenty men before
being imprisoned in an [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World
War II") [prison camp](/wiki/Prisoner-of-war_camp "Prisoner-of-war camp")
(revealed in "[The Fight](/wiki/The_Fight_\(The_Office\) "The Fight \(The
Office\)")"), implying that he was a [soldier](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") in the
[German army](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht"). In "[Dunder Mifflin
Infinity](/wiki/Dunder_Mifflin_Infinity "Dunder Mifflin Infinity")", Dwight
tells the documentary film crew that his grandfather is (at the time of the
episode) 103 years old, and is still "puttering around down in
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina")", implying that his grandfather was
one of the members of the [SS](/wiki/Schutzstaffel "Schutzstaffel") [who fled
into South America](/wiki/Ratlines_\(World_War_II\) "Ratlines \(World War
II\)"). Dwight attempted to visit him once, but his travel visa was protested
by the [Shoah Foundation](/wiki/Shoah_Foundation "Shoah Foundation").[12] In
"[Take Your Daughter to Work
Day](/wiki/Take_Your_Daughter_to_Work_Day_\(The_Office\) "Take Your Daughter
to Work Day \(The Office\)")", Michael refers to Dwight's grandmother as a
"[Nazi](/wiki/Nazi "Nazi") war criminal".[13] Dwight's father and grandfather
are also named Dwight Schrute; however, his [Amish](/wiki/Amish "Amish")
great-grandfather was named Dwide Schrude. In "[Casino
Night](/wiki/Casino_Night "Casino Night")", Dwight reveals that the
[tuxedo](/wiki/Tuxedo "Tuxedo") he is wearing is the one that his grandfather
was buried in. In a deleted scene from "[The
Surplus](/wiki/The_Surplus_\(The_Office\) "The Surplus \(The Office\)")",
Dwight tells Angela that his family came to the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_of_America "United States of America") on a
[U-boat](/wiki/U-boat "U-boat"). It is revealed in
"[Money](/wiki/Money_\(The_Office\) "Money \(The Office\)")" that it is a
tradition in the Schrute family that when a male has
[intercourse](/wiki/Sexual_intercourse "Sexual intercourse") with a woman, he
is rewarded with a bag of wild [oats](/wiki/Oats "Oats") that are left on his
doorstep by his parents. Dwight also speaks German, but his knowledge of it is
"pre-industrial and mostly [religious](/wiki/Religious "Religious")", as might
be expected if the language was learned exclusively in a Mennonite or Amish
church or context.

Dwight was [shunned](/wiki/Amish#Shunning "Amish") by his family from the age
of four until his sixth birthday, for forgetting to save the excess oil from a
can of [tuna](/wiki/Tuna "Tuna").[14] He lost a grade school [spelling
bee](/wiki/Spelling_bee "Spelling bee") to Raj Patel by misspelling the word
"failure", in front of the entire school.[15] In seventh grade, Dwight played
the invented role of "Mutey the Mailman" in a production of
_[Oklahoma!](/wiki/Oklahoma! "Oklahoma!")_ He explains that there were not
enough roles for all of the children, so they made up roles.[16]

Dwight lives in a nine-[bedroom](/wiki/Bedroom "Bedroom"),
one-[bathroom](/wiki/Bathroom "Bathroom") farmhouse (with the single bathroom
located under the porch, as revealed in "[Office
Olympics](/wiki/Office_Olympics "Office Olympics")") on his family's 60-acre
(240,000 m2) [beet](/wiki/Beet "Beet") farm, with his cousin Mose. The cousins
sell beets to local stores, restaurants, and roadside beet stands.[17] Dwight
uses part of his farm to grow [hemp](/wiki/Hemp "Hemp").[18] Dwight and Mose
have also turned Schrute Farms into a ramshackle [bed and
breakfast](/wiki/Bed_and_breakfast "Bed and breakfast"), that was visited by
Jim and Pam, during "[Money](/wiki/Money_\(The_Office\) "Money \(The
Office\)")".[19] The bed and breakfast had three theme rooms: America,
Irrigation, and Nighttime. Schrute Farms was also to be the site of Andy and
Angela's wedding before the two broke off their engagement. In "[Garden
Party](/wiki/Garden_Party_\(The_Office\) "Garden Party \(The Office\)")", Andy
throws a [garden party](/wiki/Garden_party "Garden party") at Schrute Farms in
order to impress new CEO [Robert California](/wiki/Robert_California "Robert
California"), and at the end of the episode, Robert also discusses the
possibility of holding his birthday party at the farm.

According to one of Dwight's web logs on NBC.com's "Schrute-Space", he had an
uncle, named Gunther, a [goat](/wiki/Goat "Goat") farmer, who fled the Allied
invasion of Germany and married a [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_people "Finnish
people") woman, with whom he had 17 children.[20] He also had an Uncle Girt,
who revealed that the Schrute family has an ongoing hatred of [Harry S.
Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman"), because they were staunch
supporters of [Thomas Dewey](/wiki/Thomas_Dewey "Thomas Dewey"). In another
[blog](/wiki/Blog "Blog"), he mentions a cousin named Heindl, who received
numerous injuries and infections from an attack by a small [dog](/wiki/Dog
"Dog").[21]

## Interests[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Interests")]

Dwight is trained in the art of [surveillance](/wiki/Surveillance
"Surveillance"), and is a former [Lackawanna
County](/wiki/Lackawanna_County,_Pennsylvania "Lackawanna County,
Pennsylvania") volunteer [sheriff](/wiki/Sheriff "Sheriff")'s deputy.[6] He
has a purple belt in [Goju-Ryu](/wiki/Goju-Ryu "Goju-Ryu") karate, and is the
[senpai](/wiki/Senpai_and_k%C5%8Dhai "Senpai and kōhai") at his dojo.[7]
Dwight is a [pop culture](/wiki/Pop_culture "Pop culture") and [sci-
fi](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction") enthusiast, who has expressed
fanship of many sci-fi movies and popular [television](/wiki/Television
"Television") series. In the episode "[The Fire](/wiki/The_Fire_\(The_Office\)
"The Fire \(The Office\)")", he mentioned the movie _[The
Crow](/wiki/The_Crow_\(1994_film\) "The Crow \(1994 film\)")_ as being his
favorite film. He hints at belief in fictional creatures such as
[androids](/wiki/Android_\(robot\) "Android \(robot\)"),
[zombies](/wiki/Zombies "Zombies") and [vampires](/wiki/Vampires "Vampires")
(though curiously, despite having claimed in "[Business
School](/wiki/Business_School_\(The_Office\) "Business School \(The
Office\)")", to have shot a [werewolf](/wiki/Werewolf "Werewolf") (that was
actually his neighbor's dog), he says in one of his blog entries that he does
not believe in them; however, he may have simply been denying claims of
werewolves at Schrute Farms in order to prevent potential visitors from being
frightened away).[21] He enjoys, and is shown to be skilled at, playing [table
tennis](/wiki/Table_tennis "Table tennis"), and states that many of his heroes
are table tennis players.[22] His musical tastes vary, but [heavy
metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music") and [classic
rock](/wiki/Classic_rock "Classic rock") seem to be a recurring theme.[1] His
personal musical talents are not lacking, as he plays [guitar](/wiki/Guitar
"Guitar") and [recorder](/wiki/Recorder_\(musical_instrument\) "Recorder
\(musical instrument\)"), and sings, as well.[13] He has a fascination with
cars; he usually checks a car's suspension, especially [muscle
cars](/wiki/Muscle_cars "Muscle cars"). He drives a 1987 [Pontiac Trans
Am](/wiki/Pontiac_Trans_Am "Pontiac Trans Am") though in the [Finale (The
Office)](/wiki/Finale_\(The_Office\) "Finale \(The Office\)") he's driving a
2013 [Dodge Challenger](/wiki/Dodge_Challenger "Dodge Challenger"). His
technological talents are limited, but he shows a passion for the online role
playing game _[Second Life](/wiki/Second_Life "Second Life")_ , in which the
only differences between himself and his [avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(computing\)
"Avatar \(computing\)") is that his avatar has the last name 'Shelford' and
the ability to [fly](/wiki/Flight "Flight").[18] He also shows an interest in
[trains](/wiki/Trains "Trains"), as he is restoring a turn-of-the-century
[steam engine](/wiki/Steam_engine "Steam engine") in his
[slaughterhouse](/wiki/Slaughterhouse "Slaughterhouse"), during "[The
Meeting](/wiki/The_Meeting_\(The_Office\) "The Meeting \(The Office\)")",
which has him bonding with [Toby Flenderson](/wiki/Toby_Flenderson "Toby
Flenderson"), as they share the same interest. In "[Todd
Packer](/wiki/Todd_Packer_\(The_Office\) "Todd Packer \(The Office\)")", it is
revealed that Dwight does not know who [Justin Bieber](/wiki/Justin_Bieber
"Justin Bieber") is, asking Jim "Who is Justice Beaver?", leaving Jim to
answer "A crime-fighting [beaver](/wiki/Beaver "Beaver")."

Dwight owns an impressive array of weaponry. In addition to [Laser
Tag](/wiki/Laser_Tag "Laser Tag") and [paintball](/wiki/Paintball "Paintball")
equipment, he has a [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow "Crossbow") range at his farm
("[Office Olympics](/wiki/Office_Olympics "Office Olympics")") and, when he
was named official Security Supervisor of the Scranton branch,[6] hinted that
he might bring a [bo staff](/wiki/Bo_\(weapon\) "Bo \(weapon\)") to work. He
maintained a hidden arsenal of weapons around the office, including [pepper
spray](/wiki/Pepper_spray "Pepper spray"), [nunchucks](/wiki/Nunchaku
"Nunchaku"), [throwing stars](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken"), a [stun
gun](/wiki/Electroshock_weapon "Electroshock weapon"), a
[boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang"), [handcuffs](/wiki/Handcuffs
"Handcuffs"), a [nightstick](/wiki/Club_\(weapon\) "Club \(weapon\)"), a pair
of [brass knuckles](/wiki/Brass_knuckles "Brass knuckles") and a [Chinese
sword](/wiki/Jian "Jian"), all of which were confiscated by Toby.[23] Dwight
also claimed to have sat at his desk for an entire day with a [spud
gun](/wiki/Spud_gun "Spud gun"), without any difficulty from Security.[6]
Dwight also uses a real [gun](/wiki/Gun "Gun"), a [Colt
Anaconda](/wiki/Colt_Anaconda "Colt Anaconda"), fired within city limits, to
start off the race in "[Fun Run](/wiki/Fun_Run "Fun Run")".[24] In "[Branch
Wars](/wiki/Branch_Wars "Branch Wars")", he produces a disturbing number of
[Molotov cocktails](/wiki/Molotov_cocktail "Molotov cocktail") for a
[panty](/wiki/Underwear "Underwear") raid on [Utica](/wiki/Utica,_New_York
"Utica, New York"). In "[Survivor Man](/wiki/Survivor_Man "Survivor Man")", it
is revealed that Dwight still has numerous [knives](/wiki/Knives "Knives")
(and other weapons) hidden on himself (as in "[Stress
Relief](/wiki/Stress_Relief "Stress Relief")", there is a knife strapped to
his leg) or strategically positioned throughout the office (such as "Mr. A
Knife" in a filing cabinet, twin sais behind a water cooler, a
[sword](/wiki/Sword "Sword") in a ceiling tile, a [blow dart](/wiki/Blowgun
"Blowgun") in a bathroom stall, and a [compound bow](/wiki/Compound_bow
"Compound bow") under a couch), and that he owns a .22 [rifle](/wiki/Rifle
"Rifle") with [scope](/wiki/Telescopic_sight "Telescopic sight"). Also, in
this episode, it is shown that Dwight has extensive knowledge of how to
survive in the [wilderness](/wiki/Wilderness "Wilderness"), being able to
provide himself with food, and, by observing Michael, from a distance, through
the scope of his center-fire rifle, he stops Michael from poisoning himself,
although it is not clear whether the [mushrooms](/wiki/Mushrooms "Mushrooms")
Michael started to ingest were actually poisonous.[25]

Dwight is vocal about his views on justice, which is reflected in his
television viewing habits, as he enjoys watching and has great admiration for
[Judge Judy](/wiki/Judith_Sheindlin "Judith Sheindlin"), as well as [Vic
Mackey](/wiki/Vic_Mackey "Vic Mackey") on _[The Shield](/wiki/The_Shield "The
Shield")_. In "[The Negotiation](/wiki/The_Negotiation "The Negotiation")",
[Roy Anderson](/wiki/Roy_Anderson_\(The_Office\) "Roy Anderson \(The
Office\)") attacks Jim, because he kissed Roy's [fiancee](/wiki/Fiancee
"Fiancee"), Pam, but Dwight intercepts the attack with [pepper
spray](/wiki/Pepper_spray "Pepper spray").[23] Throughout the episode, Jim
attempts to show his appreciation, but Dwight refuses to accept his gifts,
simply stating "[Citizens](/wiki/Citizens "Citizens") do not accept prizes for
being citizens".[23] In ["Drug
Testing"](/wiki/Drug_Testing_\(The_Office_episode\) "Drug Testing \(The Office
episode\)"), Dwight finds half of a [joint](/wiki/Cannabis_\(drug\) "Cannabis
\(drug\)") in the parking lot, which incites him to carry out a severe, and
thorough, investigation.[6] When he discovers that Michael might have been
exposed to illegal drugs at a concert, he substitutes his own
[urine](/wiki/Urine "Urine") during the mandatory drug test.[6] Dwight then
resigns from his volunteer position at the Sheriff's Department, because he
feels that he is no longer worthy of working there. In "[Frame
Toby](/wiki/Frame_Toby "Frame Toby")", Dwight states that he is skilled at
framing people, as well as [animals](/wiki/Animals "Animals"), revealing that
he once framed a [raccoon](/wiki/Raccoon "Raccoon") for opening a
[Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas") gift, and a [bear](/wiki/Bear "Bear")
for eating out of the [garbage](/wiki/Garbage "Garbage"), although, he had
made it obvious to the [police](/wiki/Police "Police") that he wanted Toby to
be imprisoned.[6] In the episode "[Women's
Appreciation](/wiki/Women%27s_Appreciation "Women's Appreciation")", he is
quoted as saying "Better a thousand innocent men are locked up, than one
guilty man roam free."

In "[Conflict Resolution](/wiki/Conflict_Resolution_\(The_Office\) "Conflict
Resolution \(The Office\)")", Dwight states that he does not like to smile, as
showing one's teeth is a submission signal in [primates](/wiki/Primates
"Primates"), and that whenever someone smiles at him, "all [he] sees is a
[chimpanzee](/wiki/Chimpanzee "Chimpanzee"), begging for its life". Dwight
owns many exotic pets including [piranhas](/wiki/Piranhas "Piranhas"),
[frogs](/wiki/Frogs "Frogs"), an [arctic wolf](/wiki/Arctic_wolf "Arctic
wolf"), a [raccoon](/wiki/Raccoon "Raccoon"), a porcupine named Henrietta, and
an [opossum](/wiki/Opossum "Opossum"), although the wolf escaped due to poor
restraints and he flushed his piranhas down the toilet. He also has an
interest in [bears](/wiki/Bear "Bear"), and is ready to debate the habits and
characteristics of different species of bears. He also has expressed a
surprisingly large affection towards baby otters.

In "[Costume Contest](/wiki/Costume_Contest "Costume Contest")", Dwight claims
to be able to sit on a fence, and that he is even able to sleep on one,
stating that "The trick is to do it face down, with the post in your mouth".

It is revealed in the "Suit Warehouse" episode that as a child Dwight
collected cat feces.

##
Relationships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Relationships")]

In "[Drug Testing](/wiki/Drug_Testing_\(The_Office\) "Drug Testing \(The
Office\)")", Dwight states that he likes his co-workers, "with four
exceptions", leaving it up to the audience to make educated guesses about whom
these four exceptions are. The four are most likely [Jim
Halpert](/wiki/Jim_Halpert "Jim Halpert"), [Ryan
Howard](/wiki/Ryan_Howard_\(The_Office\) "Ryan Howard \(The Office\)"),
[Meredith Palmer](/wiki/Meredith_Palmer "Meredith Palmer") and [Toby
Flenderson](/wiki/Toby_Flenderson "Toby Flenderson"), due to Michael's hatred
of him. However, it is also probable that [Phyllis Lapin-
Vance](/wiki/Phyllis_Lapin-Vance "Phyllis Lapin-Vance") could be one of the
exceptions, as, on many occasions, she and Dwight are shown to have a strained
relationship. [Kelly Kapoor](/wiki/Kelly_Kapoor "Kelly Kapoor") is likewise a
viable choice as her ditsy nature contrasts Dwight's overly serious character,
as we see later in the same episode during Dwight's interrogation of Kelly.
This theory is also reinforced by Angela's hatred of Kelly and the influence
Angela may hold as Dwight's girlfriend at the time. Pam Halpert is also a
possible exception as she is often an accomplice to Jim's pranks against
Dwight.

### Angela
Martin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Angela Martin")]

Towards the middle of season 2, Dwight develops a secret relationship with
Angela Martin. Pam begins to suspect a relationship between the two, in
"[E-mail Surveillance](/wiki/E-mail_Surveillance "E-mail Surveillance")", by
observing their interactions, suspicions which are strengthened in "[The
Injury](/wiki/The_Injury "The Injury")" and "[Conflict
Resolution](/wiki/Conflict_Resolution_\(The_Office\) "Conflict Resolution
\(The Office\)")", and confirmed by "[Traveling
Salesmen](/wiki/Traveling_Salesmen_\(The_Office\) "Traveling Salesmen \(The
Office\)")", where Angela confides in Pam about her relationship, using code
names.[1] In "[Michael's Birthday](/wiki/Michael%27s_Birthday "Michael's
Birthday")", Ryan discovers the relationship between the two when he overhears
a coded conversation between them in the kitchen, while in "The Negotiation"
Jim discovers the relationship while coming out of the office bathroom after
quitting time, to find Dwight and Angela kissing (he then tells the
documentary crew that, with his silence, the debt he feels to Dwight is
repaid).[23]

In the episode "[Fun Run](/wiki/Fun_Run "Fun Run")", Angela asks Dwight to
care for her sick cat, Sprinkles. Instead of caring for the feline, Dwight
feels he should [kill it as a waste of resources](/wiki/Animal_euthanasia
"Animal euthanasia"), and then tells Angela Sprinkles was dead when he
arrived.[24] When he lets the truth slip out shortly after, Angela terminates
their relationship. Jim, on a visit to Dwight's beet farm, finds Dwight
sitting alone at night, contemplating Angela's [cherub](/wiki/Cherub "Cherub")
[figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") and moaning in anguish.[19]

In the [fourth season](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_4\) "The Office \(U.S.
season 4\)") finale "[Goodbye, Toby](/wiki/Goodbye,_Toby "Goodbye, Toby")",
Dwight is obviously hurt when Angela's boyfriend, Andy, proposes to her.
However, in the final scene of the episode, Phyllis catches Dwight [having
sex](/wiki/Having_sex "Having sex") with Angela in the office.[26]

In the [fifth season](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_5\) "The Office \(U.S.
season 5\)") premiere, "[Weight Loss](/wiki/Weight_Loss_\(The_Office\) "Weight
Loss \(The Office\)")", Dwight and Angela have resumed a covert relationship,
using a storage room in the warehouse to have sex. In "[Crime
Aid](/wiki/Crime_Aid "Crime Aid")", Andy and Angela set a date for their
wedding. After some advice from Phyllis, Dwight gives Angela an ultimatum:
call off the engagement, or he will no longer be with her. She chooses to
marry Andy. When Andy learns about Angela's affair with Dwight, [a
duel](/wiki/The_Duel_\(The_Office\) "The Duel \(The Office\)") between Dwight
and Andy takes place, but both realize that Angela has been lying to them, and
break up with her. For quite some time afterwards, Dwight and Angela avoid
each other.

In the [season 6](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_6\) "The Office \(U.S. season
6\)") episode "[The Delivery](/wiki/The_Delivery_\(The_Office\) "The Delivery
\(The Office\)")", Dwight, witnessing Jim and Pam talk to customers about
their unborn child, decides that he wants a child, and asks Angela to be the
mother. They sign an elaborate contract, including eating guidelines for
Angela to follow when she is [pregnant](/wiki/Pregnant "Pregnant"), and how
the baby will be raised. While Angela is excited by the reconciliation, Dwight
doesn't share her romantic feelings. When Dwight develops an interest in Pam's
friend Isabel, he tells Angela to forget about the contract; this infuriates
Angela and she sues him in small-claims court. When an arbitrator tells them
that the contract is valid and would involve a $30,000 settlement (because it
would be illegal to force Dwight and Angela to procreate), Dwight cuts a deal
with Angela for five sessions of sex. He then proceeds to abuse his genitals
in an effort to sterilize himself, and fends off Angela's efforts to be
romantic.

In [Season 7](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_7\) "The Office \(U.S. season
7\)"), after Angela meets a [state senator](/wiki/State_senator "State
senator") who she finds much more personable than Dwight, she voids the pact
in [WUPHF.com](/wiki/WUPHF.com "WUPHF.com").

In "[Jury Duty](/wiki/Jury_Duty_\(The_Office\) "Jury Duty \(The Office\)")",
it is revealed that, a month before her wedding to the state senator, [Robert
Lipton](/wiki/List_of_characters_from_The_Office_\(U.S._TV_series\)#Robert_Lipton
"List of characters from The Office \(U.S. TV series\)"), Dwight and Angela
had sex, as Robert was not fulfilling Angela's sexual needs, so Dwight
believes that he is the baby's biological father.[27] In "[New
Guys](/wiki/New_Guys "New Guys")", it is revealed that he is not the father.

In season 9, they become close again first when Dwight finds out that Robert
is cheating on Angela with Oscar, and later in "[Moving
On](/wiki/Moving_On_\(The_Office\) "Moving On \(The Office\)")" when Angela
helps him take care of his elderly aunt. They share a kiss, but afterwards
both say that she should remain faithful to her husband. After inheriting his
aunt's beet farm, Dwight starts a relationship with neighboring brusselsprout
farmer Esther Bruegger ([Nora Kirkpatrick](/wiki/Nora_Kirkpatrick "Nora
Kirkpatrick")). When Dwight seems to be getting serious with Esther and the
Senator has publicly dumped Angela, Angela breaks down and admits to [Oscar
Martinez](/wiki/Oscar_Martinez_\(The_Office\) "Oscar Martinez \(The Office\)")
that she still loves Dwight. On the day that he intends to ask Esther to marry
him, Dwight instead proposes to Angela. She says yes, finally admitting that
he is the father of her son Phillip. ("[A.A.R.M.](/wiki/A.A.R.M. "A.A.R.M.")")

### Michael
Scott[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Michael Scott")]

Dwight holds a high level of respect for Michael, viewing him as a model for
success, and often participating with Michael's ill-conceived schemes.[2]
However, he betrays Michael numerous times, such as when he goes over
Michael's head to vie for the manager's job in "[The
Coup](/wiki/The_Coup_\(The_Office\) "The Coup \(The Office\)")". Despite this,
Michael frequently dismisses Dwight and often appears embarrassed by his
antics; for much of the series, he also refuses to promote Dwight from
"Assistant to the Regional Manager" to "Assistant Regional Manager". In later
seasons, Dwight was shown to return the favor, such as Dwight telling Michael
that he would have a better career if he'd taken a job at Home Depot. Several
times throughout the series, however, it is revealed that Michael does care
about Dwight's feelings, and the two sometimes share bonding moments. In
"[Training Day](/wiki/Training_Day_\(The_Office\) "Training Day \(The
Office\)")", Dwight is unhappy when the open branch manager position goes to
[Deangelo Vickers](/wiki/Deangelo_Vickers "Deangelo Vickers"), and when he
learns that Michael did not recommend him for the job, as he led him to
believe, he snubs Michael and goes to a meeting Vickers has called, leaving
Michael standing outside, by himself. In "[Goodbye,
Michael](/wiki/Goodbye,_Michael "Goodbye, Michael")", Dwight is still
frustrated with Michael, but his hostility turns into heartfelt appreciation
as Michael hands him the recommendation letter. At first, the letter does not
seem to impress him, but, as he reads through, he realizes that Michael really
does respect him. They are later seen engaging in a friendly paintball fight,
and Dwight's loyalty to Michael is once again restored. Also, after Michael
left, Dwight did not have the same respect for Deangelo and Andy that Dwight
previously had for Michael, implying that Dwight truly respects and values
Michael. In a deleted scene from "Finale", Dwight stated that Michael sent him
his "World's Best Boss" mug when he became Regional Manager.

In the episode "Finale", as Jim explains that the "Bestest Mench" (best man)
in Dwight's wedding must be older than him, Dwight is disappointed. However,
the camera reveals that Michael returned, and the two continue to engage in a
friendly conversation. During the wedding, Michael is present behind Angela
and Dwight getting married, eventually attending the reception. He watches as
his "family" is sitting together, and is last seen dancing with Dwight.

### Jim Halpert[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Jim Halpert")]

Dwight is frequently the victim of practical jokes by co-workers Jim Halpert
and Pam Beesly, including putting his desk supplies in the snack machine,
putting his stapler into jello, and moving his desk into the men's restroom,
although it appears that he remains oblivious to Pam's involvement; these
pranks tend to exploit his stubborn and gullible nature. Dwight's frustration
with Jim's pranks reaches a crisis point in "[Conflict
Resolution](/wiki/Conflict_Resolution_\(The_Office\) "Conflict Resolution
\(The Office\)")", when Dwight threatens to quit unless Jim is
transferred.[28] Dwight occasionally pulls successful pranks on Jim in turn,
most prominently in "[Classy Christmas](/wiki/Classy_Christmas "Classy
Christmas")" where he subjects Jim to a barrage of pranks revolving around
snowballs. Professionally, Dwight wins the 2005 Salesman of the Year Award,
although, this is likely due to, at least in part, his theft of Jim's largest
client.[15]

During "[Initiation](/wiki/Initiation_\(The_Office\) "Initiation \(The
Office\)")", Dwight tells Ryan he regrets that he and Jim never got along. In
"[Traveling Salesmen](/wiki/Traveling_Salesmen_\(The_Office\) "Traveling
Salesmen \(The Office\)")", Dwight quits and hugs Jim as a farewell which
surprises Jim as he does not know that Dwight quit. Later, Jim is irritated
when Andy replaces Dwight and even says that he misses Dwight. Earlier in the
same episode, Jim and Dwight make an incredibly efficient sales team,
functioning well as a duo and thinking similarly in their tactics. The two
were paired together when they began as traveling salesmen at the company.
Dwight plans to demote Jim from the Assistant Regional Manager spot, and make
him miserable, during "[The Job](/wiki/The_Job_\(The_Office\) "The Job \(The
Office\)")".[29]

Dwight's relationship with Jim mellows somewhat in later seasons, and they, at
times, cooperate effectively on sales calls or running the office in Michael's
absence, sometimes even socializing together. Jim often supports Dwight when
he is genuinely hurt or in danger (such as in
"[Money](/wiki/Money_\(The_Office\) "Money \(The Office\)")" and "[Last Day in
Florida](/wiki/Last_Day_in_Florida "Last Day in Florida")") and occasionally
compliments his successes (such as in "[Dwight K. Schrute, (Acting)
Manager](/wiki/Dwight_K._Schrute,_\(Acting\)_Manager "Dwight K. Schrute,
\(Acting\) Manager")"). However, when Jim is promoted to co-manager, Dwight's
enmity returns to full force, and he conducts an ongoing campaign to depose
Jim, who eventually resumes his old job as sales representative in "[Manager
and Salesman](/wiki/Manager_and_Salesman "Manager and Salesman")".

Jim and Dwight team up in "[Todd Packer](/wiki/Todd_Packer_\(The_Office\)
"Todd Packer \(The Office\)")" to remove [Todd Packer](/wiki/Todd_Packer "Todd
Packer") after he returns to the Dunder Mifflin offices and takes Dwight's
desk. The two at first cannot agree on a plan, but eventually trick Packer
into thinking he has got a job offer in Tallahassee.[30]

During "[After Hours](/wiki/After_Hours_\(The_Office\) "After Hours \(The
Office\)")", Jim enlists Dwight into trying to get Kathy, an unwanted female
suitor, out of his room by tricking Dwight into thinking that he has bedbugs.
This prompts Dwight to overreact, first by stripping down to ward off bugs and
then spraying Jim's bed with cleaning chemicals. However, the ploy works when
Kathy exits the room. Jim and Dwight are then shown sharing ice cream and a
friendly smile in Dwight's room, while watching TV on his bed, where it is
implied Jim will have to stay the night due to the chemicals in his own room,
as earlier Dwight suggested Jim stay with Kathy. In "[Last Day in
Florida](/wiki/Last_Day_in_Florida "Last Day in Florida")", Robert California
confides to Jim that he's going to terminate Dwight's plans to launch the
Sabre store, effectively terminating Dwight's job altogether. Jim tries to let
Dwight know, who dismisses his warnings as nothing more than just another
prank and insults Jim throughout the day, including in front of the other
Sabre staff. At Pam's insistence, Jim tries to tell Dwight one more time
before he's dismissed, just as Dwight is about to accept what he thinks is his
promotion in the board room. However, Jim physically attacks Dwight just
before he goes in, and the two had a wrestling match to which Jim finally
concedes. When Dwight steps in, he sees that Packer, who has stolen Dwight's
promotion in the meantime, takes the fall and is promptly fired by Robert in
the meeting. Defeated, Dwight walks out of the boardroom and lends Jim a hand
up and returns to Scranton. When Kelly sees Dwight, she mentions that she
thought Dwight was staying in Florida, prompting Jim to distract her with a
compliment.

During season 9's "[Dwight Christmas](/wiki/Dwight_Christmas "Dwight
Christmas")", Dwight is convinced by Jim to hold a traditional Christmas party
in the style of his family. Jim must leave before the party is over and Dwight
is noticeably emotionally upset when Jim must leave. Later, when Jim returns,
Dwight embraces him in a hug. Soon after, in "[Suit
Warehouse](/wiki/Suit_Warehouse "Suit Warehouse")", Dwight absent-mindedly
says "love you" at the end of a phone conversation with Jim, much to his
embarrassment and the bemusement of his coworkers.

In "[Livin' the Dream](/wiki/Livin%27_the_Dream "Livin' the Dream")", the 3rd-
to-last episode of the series, Jim suggests to [David
Wallace](/wiki/David_Wallace_\(The_Office\) "David Wallace \(The Office\)")
that Dwight deserves to replace [Andy Bernard](/wiki/Andy_Bernard "Andy
Bernard") as Regional Manager because Dwight loves paper more than anyone
else. David agrees and Dwight is promoted to Regional Manager at the end of
the episode as a result; Dwight subsequently appoints Jim to fill his old
position, Assistant to the Regional Manager.

In the final episode of the series "[Finale](/wiki/Finale_\(The_Office\)
"Finale \(The Office\)")", Dwight asks Jim to be the best man at his wedding.
Jim throws Dwight a commendable bachelor party rife with surprises (which Jim
refers to as "pranks"). Before the wedding Jim informs Dwight that, under
Schrute tradition, he is not allowed to be best man as he is younger than him.
Jim surprises him with the arrival of [Michael
Scott](/wiki/Michael_Scott_\(The_Office\) "Michael Scott \(The Office\)"). The
wedding proceeds in Schrute tradition with Michael as Dwight's new best man.
Later in the episode Jim and Pam tell Dwight they are quitting so Jim can
pursue a sports marketing career in Austin, but Dwight fires them instead so
he can give them [severance packages](/wiki/Severance_package "Severance
package").

### Pam Halpert[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Pam Halpert")]

Although she is often involved in Jim's pranks on Dwight, Dwight has, at
certain times, displayed a curious sense of protectiveness towards her. In
"[Back from Vacation](/wiki/Back_from_Vacation "Back from Vacation")" and
"[Diwali](/wiki/Diwali_\(The_Office\) "Diwali \(The Office\)")", he comforts a
tearful Pam, and in "[China](/wiki/China_\(The_Office\) "China \(The
Office\)")", he secretly allows Pam to [save
face](/wiki/Face_\(sociological_concept\) "Face \(sociological concept\)")
when she feels vulnerable about her job abilities. In "[The
Job](/wiki/The_Job_\(The_Office\) "The Job \(The Office\)")", Dwight offers
Pam the position of "Secret Assistant to the Regional Manager", and following
Jim's advice concerning any offers from Dwight to be involved in something
secret, she accepts. Though Jim presumably meant this as the opening move of a
prank, Pam instead uses it as a bonding opportunity between her and Dwight.

The two briefly become best friends while he suffers a
[concussion](/wiki/Concussion "Concussion") in "[The Injury](/wiki/The_Injury
"The Injury")". In the season 6 episode "[The
Delivery](/wiki/The_Delivery_\(The_Office\) "The Delivery \(The Office\)")",
Dwight shows more signs of his begrudging friendship with Jim and Pam during
Pam's pregnancy. In the episode, he is sent to the Halperts' house to retrieve
Pam's [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod"), while they are at the hospital. Instead of
finding the iPod and bringing it back to her, Dwight completely rebuilds and
repaints their kitchen, after discovering [mold](/wiki/Mold "Mold"). He also
advises Pam on how to keep her daughter, Cece, from crying, during "[Viewing
Party](/wiki/Viewing_Party "Viewing Party")", by relating his child rearing
experiences. Dwight's odd friendship with Pam is explored again in
"[Doomsday](/wiki/Doomsday_\(The_Office\) "Doomsday \(The Office\)")". At this
point, Pam is the only one in the office who is able to understand Dwight's
inner feelings, as she successfully convinces him to deactivate his doomsday
machine. It is implied at the end of the episode that Dwight, despite his
outward contempt for his coworkers, feels a sense of responsibility (and
possibly even affection) towards them.

In a talking-head interview, in the episode
"[Tallahassee](/wiki/Tallahassee_\(The_Office\) "Tallahassee \(The
Office\)")", Dwight talks about how first impressions last forever. He recalls
that, when he first met Pam, she said something to him that "slightly rubbed
[him] the wrong way", and while he has since loved working with her, even
stating that she is wonderful, due to that first impression, he hates her. In
the episode "The Whale", Dwight openly tells Pam that he considers her his
friend. In the final episode of the series, Dwight refers to Pam as his "best
friend", and he ensures that she and Jim get a large severance as they leave
Dunder Mifflin.

### Andy
Bernard[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Andy Bernard")]

As a result of the Scranton-Stamford merger, Dwight loses his number two
position to Jim and engages in an ongoing battle with new salesman [Andy
Bernard](/wiki/Andy_Bernard "Andy Bernard"), to gain Michael's favor for
"third-in-command". The struggle comes to a climax in "[Traveling
Salesmen](/wiki/Traveling_Salesmen_\(The_Office\) "Traveling Salesmen \(The
Office\)")".[1] In Season 4, Andy and Dwight are shown to work well together
as a sales team, but Andy's successful pursuit of Angela, after she broke up
with Dwight, was irritating to him. When Andy gets engaged to Angela, Dwight
is greatly upset by this, and embarks on an affair with her. This affair
culminates in a short-lived fight between Andy and Dwight, when they discover
Angela has lied to both of them, about not having had sex with the other. In
"[Michael Scott Paper Company](/wiki/Michael_Scott_Paper_Company "Michael
Scott Paper Company")," they once again find themselves courting the same
woman – [Erin Hannon](/wiki/Erin_Hannon "Erin Hannon"). However, by the end of
the fifth season, Andy and Dwight become friends, and discover they both share
a mutual interest in music and hunting.[31]

### Ryan
Howard[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Ryan Howard")]

In the beginning of the series, Dwight feels threatened by [Ryan
Howard](/wiki/Ryan_Howard_\(The_Office\) "Ryan Howard \(The Office\)"), to
whom Michael often assigns personal tasks. He continues to resent Ryan,
throughout the second season, often addressing him as "Temp",[4] even after
Ryan took over Jim's position.[12] In the beginning of season 2, Dwight's
friendship with Michael was slightly torn during "[The
Fire](/wiki/The_Fire_\(The_Office\) "The Fire \(The Office\)")", when Michael
seems to be viewing Ryan more favorably than Dwight, and in "[Performance
Review](/wiki/Performance_Review "Performance Review")", in which Michael must
evaluate Ryan.[32] In "[Initiation](/wiki/Initiation_\(The_Office\)
"Initiation \(The Office\)")", Dwight decides to assist Ryan, during his first
sales call, although the two get off to a rough start when Dwight
[hazes](/wiki/Hazing "Hazing") him in a series of bizarre initiation rituals.
Soon afterwards, Dwight takes Ryan on his first meeting, which ends in
disaster. Ryan then eggs the potential customer's building out of spite, and
Dwight develops some respect for him.[33]

During season 4, Dwight, along with Michael, comes to Ryan's rescue when they
visit him in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), when he
gets into a scuffle.

Ryan and Dwight later team up again in season 6, when Dwight plans to sabotage
Jim's occupation, as branch co-manager.[34]

### Romantic
relationships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Romantic relationships")]

A subtle running joke throughout the series is Dwight's surprising success
with attractive women, with Michael often failing to "hook up" at the same
time. Despite Dwight's unusual appearance and mannerisms, he manages to
attract women, who usually develop stronger feelings for him than vice versa.
Michael has even pointed out how socially weird Dwight is acting, only for the
woman to brush it off. In "[Night Out](/wiki/Night_Out_\(The_Office\) "Night
Out \(The Office\)")", Dwight hooks up with a women's
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") player, while Michael fails in his
attempts with other women. As Michael and Dwight leave the club, the woman
calls out for Dwight to call her, which he says to Michael that he will not
do. In "[Niagara](/wiki/Niagara_\(The_Office\) "Niagara \(The Office\)")",
Michael and Dwight compete for the attention of Pam's best friend, Isabel.
When Dwight starts talking about his farm, Michael tries to explain that no
one can connect with his experiences as farmer, only for Isabel to become
interested in Dwight's [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse"). Dwight ultimately
manages to have sex with her, and she begins to develop deeper feelings for
him which he does not return, although it is finally hinted in "[The
Delivery](/wiki/The_Delivery_\(The_Office\) "The Delivery \(The Office\)")"
that Dwight might have more intimate feelings for her than he originally let
on. They meet again at the bar in "[Happy
Hour](/wiki/Happy_Hour_\(The_Office\) "Happy Hour \(The Office\)")", and bond
further, kissing at the end of the episode. In a chat at OfficeTally.com,
[Mindy Kaling](/wiki/Mindy_Kaling "Mindy Kaling") noted that Dwight is not a
typical "nerd" character, that he is a "farmer and kind of strapping and
tall", and it generally makes sense that he does well with the opposite sex.
In season 9, he begins to date an attractive neighboring farmer named Esther
([Nora Kirkpatrick](/wiki/Nora_Kirkpatrick "Nora Kirkpatrick")). He ultimately
ends his relationship with her in "[A.A.R.M.](/wiki/A.A.R.M. "A.A.R.M.")". In
the final episode, Dwight marries [Angela Martin](/wiki/Angela_Martin "Angela
Martin").

## Character
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Character reception")]

The Dwight Schrute character has had a very positive reception, and is often
cited as one of the most popular characters on the show. According to
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ he
is one of the "greatest sidekicks."[35] In [TV Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide "TV
Guide")'s list of the top 100 characters in television history, Dwight was
ranked 85th. In an [ABC News](/wiki/ABC_News "ABC News") interview with Rainn
Wilson, the interviewer commented that "Words barely describe Dwight Schrute,
the suck-up salesman and assistant to the regional manager of the Scranton
branch for the Dunder Mifflin Paper Company..."[36] and "Dwight, as played by
the 41-year-old Wilson, has become one of the breakout characters in
television comedy. Dwight is a survivalist geek, a student of karate who likes
to shoot a crossbow and watch "Battlestar Galactica" on television. And he
takes himself very, very seriously..."[36] [E! News](/wiki/E!_News "E! News")
commented that Rainn Wilson should be nominated for an [Emmy
Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") for his performance of Dwight,
commenting: "...Who's laughing now? Who's laughing now, Dwight Schrute? Oh,
only the ten million-plus people who watched as you pepper sprayed the living
daylights out of Roy for trying to pop Jim in the face last night. My God,
have I missed you, man. Mr. Schrute, you are the reason I love my job, my
friend. It is the selflessly heroic actions of a man such as you that make
television a nice place to be on a Thursday night. You may just be an everyday
citizen who does not accept prizes for being a citizen, but you'd best be
accepting a supporting actor Emmy nod this year, because, hot damn if you
don't deserve it."[37]

Another positive review of the character was given by PopMatters, an online
entertainment news site. The review stated: "One of the show’s ironies is that
Michael and Dwight, hapless though they might be within the office or in most
social settings, are actually top salesmen...Undeterred, or unaware of any of
this, Dwight carries on with his dreams of grandeur, even instituting a reward
system called "Schrute Bucks" for employees who please him during a brief but
tyrannical reign as branch manager...Dwight approaches sales with the same
militaristic fervor as everything else in his life, and it pays off for him
(maybe that’s one of the reasons why, when Jim gives Dwight one of Benito
Mussolini’s speeches to deliver when he accepts a sales award in Season Two,
Dwight delivers it so enthusiastically that he gets a standing
ovation)..."[38] [Metalcore](/wiki/Metalcore "Metalcore") band [The Devil
Wears Prada](/wiki/The_Devil_Wears_Prada_\(band\) "The Devil Wears Prada
\(band\)") named a song "Assistant to the Regional Manager," alluding to
Dwight's position. In addition, the band created a T-shirt design that
indirectly associates itself with Dwight by strongly resembling him. It is
named "Guy Wearing Tie."[39]

## Outside of _The
Office_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Outside of The Office")]

### Bobblehead
doll[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Bobblehead doll")]

In the episode "[Valentine's
Day](/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day_\(The_Office_episode\) "Valentine's Day \(The
Office episode\)")", Dwight is given a [bobblehead doll](/wiki/Bobblehead_doll
"Bobblehead doll") as a Valentine's gift, from Angela. Following the episode,
fans of the show petitioned NBC to make the bobblehead doll available for
purchase on their online store.[40] NBC responded by creating an initial run
of 4,000 bobblehead dolls, which sold out almost immediately.[40] The creator
of the show, [Greg Daniels](/wiki/Greg_Daniels "Greg Daniels"), joked about
the bobbleheads, saying "Yes, they are fun, but they also serve a business
purpose. People who want to manage by consensus can buy six and keep them
nodding all the time to whatever they say."[40] In 2010 Hallmark released a
smaller talking version of the doll as part of their 2010 Christmas Keepsake
Ornament selection.

### Résumé[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Résumé")]

In "[Halloween](/wiki/Halloween_\(The_Office\) "Halloween \(The Office\)")",
Jim and Pam uploaded Dwight's resume to "[Monster.com](/wiki/Monster.com
"Monster.com"), [Craigslist](/wiki/Craigslist "Craigslist"), and
[Google](/wiki/Google "Google")."[41] A producer actually did create a Monster
account for Dwight and uploaded his résumé a month before the episode aired.
It can be found by employers with resume database access who search for
salesmen in [Scranton, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania "Scranton,
Pennsylvania").[42] The résumé stated that he was willing to relocate to
another state,[42] wanted a salary close to $30,000 ([USD](/wiki/USD
"USD")),[42] desired the job title of Regional Manager,[42] was currently
"Assistant to the Regional Manager",[42] and had a [Bachelor's
Degree](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_Degree "Bachelor's Degree").[42] The posted résumé
also stated: "My time spent at Dunder Mifflin was very enjoying. I had the
opportunity to learn from an experienced and talented boss. My branch
consistently was one of the top sellers of the company..."[42]

### Schrute
Farms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Schrute Farms")]

In "[Money](/wiki/Money_\(The_Office_episode\) "Money \(The Office
episode\)")", Pam refers to a [TripAdvisor](/wiki/TripAdvisor "TripAdvisor")
page for Dwight's [bed and breakfast](/wiki/Bed_and_breakfast "Bed and
breakfast"). This can be found by searching for Schrute Farms.[43] Jim and Pam
discover that Dwight is running the Schrute Farm as an
"[agritourism](/wiki/Agritourism "Agritourism")" bed and breakfast. They spend
the night there, taking part in table-making demonstrations, beet wine-making,
and distributing [manure](/wiki/Manure "Manure"). That night, however, Jim
hears an unnerving moaning sound throughout the night, later shown to be
Dwight in his room crying over his breakup with Angela. The TripAdvisor page
said:

"Schrute Farms is the number one beet-related [agritourism](/wiki/Agritourism
"Agritourism") destination in Northeastern Pennsylvania. We offer the finest
accommodations for the casual traveler and/or radish enthusiast. Come join us
and experience majestic Schrute Farms."[43]

Jim and Pam ("JandP2") also posted a review, which can be seen on the reviews
page. It read: "The architecture reminds one of a quaint Tuscan beet farm, and
the natural aroma of the beets drifts into the bedrooms and makes you dream of
simpler times. You will never want to leave your room. The informative lecture
will satisfy all your beet curiosity, and the dawn goose walk will tug at your
heart strings. Table making never seemed so possible. Great story to tell your
friends. Plenty of parking! The staff's attention to detail and devotion to
cleanliness was limitless. From their enthusiastic welcome to the last wave
good-bye, Schrute Farms delivers."[43]

An angry Angela also put a review up, and mentioned the death of her cat as a
main cause for the review. It said: "I have to warn people about the
proprietor of Schrute Farms—he may portray himself as a gentleman farmer, but
he is not what he seems! He killed my cat, Sprinkles! Who knows what he might
do to you or your loved ones..."[43]

According to Dwight, during the [Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American
Civil War"), while the [Battle of Gettysburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg
"Battle of Gettysburg") was known for having the most deaths, the battle of
Schrute Farms was known for having the highest DPA (deaths per acre). He also
claimed it was the northernmost battle during the Civil War. However, in
reality, it was actually a safe haven for men who wanted relief from the war
to focus on artistic lifestyles. It is insinuated that this was a camp for
homosexual soldiers. Melvin Fifer Garris is the only known soldier to write
home from Schrute Farms during the Civil War.

### Vice presidential bid
joke[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Vice presidential bid joke")]

External video
![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-
Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png) [Rainn Wilson on The Tonight Show discussing the
"nomination"](http://www.nbc.com/The_Office/video/#mea=251910)  
---  
  
On the May 7, 2008, episode of _[The Daily Show with Jon
Stewart](/wiki/The_Daily_Show_with_Jon_Stewart "The Daily Show with Jon
Stewart")_ , [US Senator](/wiki/US_Senator "US Senator") and [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)") presidential nominee [John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John McCain")
joked that Dwight Schrute would be his vice presidential candidate
choice.[44][45] [Rainn Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson") appeared on
_[The Tonight Show](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show "The Tonight Show")_ on May 14,
2008, and read to [Jay Leno](/wiki/Jay_Leno "Jay Leno") a list of demands from
Dwight in exchange for being vice president.[46] Included in this list was
being able to pilot [Air Force One](/wiki/Air_Force_One "Air Force One") at
any time, and only to be addressed as "Iceman" while piloting.[46] He also
demanded that [Jack Bauer](/wiki/Jack_Bauer "Jack Bauer") be immediately
promoted to [United States Secretary of
Defense](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United States Secretary of
Defense"), his [bunker](/wiki/Bunker "Bunker") to include a
[foosball](/wiki/Foosball "Foosball") table and be [zombie](/wiki/Zombie
"Zombie")-proof, and that the [Secret
Service](/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service "United States Secret Service")
members be armed with [nunchakus](/wiki/Nunchaku "Nunchaku"), [throwing
stars](/wiki/Throwing_star "Throwing star"), and
[flamethrowers](/wiki/Flamethrower "Flamethrower").[46] Finally, he demanded a
flamethrower, an [Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man") suit, and that fellow
character Michael Scott be an "ambassador to [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii
"Hawaii")."[46]

### Dwight in academic
research[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Dwight in academic research")]

Researchers at [Brigham Young University](/wiki/Brigham_Young_University
"Brigham Young University"), [Stanford](/wiki/Stanford "Stanford") and
[Northwestern University](/wiki/Northwestern_University "Northwestern
University") demonstrated that social outsiders, similar to Dwight's
character, lead to better group decision making. Media accounts of their
published study reported that having a Dwight Schrute around is good for
business. Dwight was included in articles about the research by [_Time_
magazine](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)"),[47] _[Toronto Globe
and Mail](/wiki/Toronto_Globe_and_Mail "Toronto Globe and Mail")_ ,[48]
_The[Salt Lake Tribune](/wiki/Salt_Lake_Tribune "Salt Lake Tribune")_[49] and
[Brigham Young University](/wiki/Brigham_Young_University "Brigham Young
University").[50]

### Possible spin-off series and departure from _The
Office_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dwight_Schrute&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Possible spin-off series and departure from The Office")]

On January 25, 2012, news broke that NBC was planning a spin-off series,
starring Wilson as Dwight, that would be set at Schrute Farms, Dwight's bed-
and-breakfast and beet farm.[51] The spin-off was to have been created by
Wilson and executive producer [Paul Lieberstein](/wiki/Paul_Lieberstein "Paul
Lieberstein"), but _Office_ developer [Greg Daniels](/wiki/Greg_Daniels "Greg
Daniels") would not have been involved.[51] The series was in the works for a
premiere in early 2013, and would have caused Wilson to leave _The Office_
during the ninth season.[51] The spin-off was scheduled to have been
introduced as a [backdoor pilot](/wiki/Backdoor_pilot "Backdoor pilot") in a
later episode of the ninth season.[51] Despite the news report, Wilson
[tweeted](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") "Don't believe everything you read in the
press, OK?".[52] In October 2012, NBC announced that it was not accepting the
spin-off series.[53]
